definition: Gu Kaizhi or Ku K'aichih (346-407), famous painter of Eastern Jin dynasty, one of the Four Great Painters of the Six Dynasties 六朝四大家
surname Gu
to look after/to take into consideration/to attend to
joyful/kind
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it

sentences.english: Gu laid great emphasis on the three hairs, and Pei was very satisfied.
sentences.chinese: 顧愷之卻把這三根汗毛畫得特別突出，裴楷非常滿意。

sentences.english: It is said to go back to the painter Ku K'ai-chi, who lived in the fourth century AD.
sentences.chinese: 據說原本出自公元4世紀的畫家顧愷之的手筆。

sentences.english: The form for the aesthetical view of Gu Kai's has epoch-making significance.
sentences.chinese: 顧愷之美學觀的形成具有劃時代的意義。

definition: Yang Ningshi (873-954) calligrapher of 5 dynasties period between Tang and Song
letter/also written 書札|书札
Liu Gongquan (778-865), Tang calligrapher
Zhang Sengyou (active c. 490-540), one of the Four Great Painters of the Six Dynasties 六朝四大家
to trace over/to copy (a calligraphy model)/facsimile/(fig.) to depict/to portray
A New Account of the Tales of the World, collection of anecdotes, conversations, remarks etc of historic personalities, compiled and edited by Liu Yiqing 劉義慶|刘义庆[Liu2 Yi4 qing4]
variant of 模擬|模拟[mo2 ni3]
calligraphic style of Liu Gongquan
great calligraphy master/the Sage of Calligraphy, traditional reference to Wang Xizhi 王羲之[Wang2 Xi1 zhi1] (303-361)
Ouyang Xun (557-641), one of Four Great Calligraphers of early Tang 唐初四大家[Tang2 chu1 Si4 Da4 jia1]
regular script (Chinese calligraphic style)
Tao Zongyi (c. 1329-1410), Yuan dynasty scholar
accurate depiction of architectural forms with the aid of a ruler (technique of Chinese art)/picture created using this technique
Zhong Yao (151-230), minister of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4] and noted calligrapher, said to have developed the regular script 楷書|楷书[kai3 shu1]
founding master of a monastery/founder/originator
Lu Ji (261-303), Chinese writer and literary critic
